subject: Re: [junit] Testing Abstract classes, private methods?
msgSnippet: ... Abstract classes can t be instantiated, so you can t test them directly. I d use a concrete subclass of the abstract class for testing. ... Ooh. This one
messageBody:
On Mon, 26 Feb 2001, Ajit Bhat wrote:

> Hi,
>
> I'm new to JUnit. Could anybody tell me how to test abstract classes?

Abstract classes can't be instantiated, so you can't test them directly.
I'd use a concrete subclass of the abstract class for testing.

> How to test private methods in a class?

Ooh. This one is a religious battle. The answer depends upon how dearly
you love encapsulation philosophy.

If you want to test the private method directly, one method is to
provide a more-accessible test method which exercises the private
method. Your unit test would call the more-accessible test method.

Another method is to inspect the class for more-accessible methods
which use the private method, and craft a test which excercises the
private method via the more-accessible method.

If your method is using default access, create a test class which
extends the class and write tests on/for the test class.

The method I use for my current project is to just set the private
method to protected instead of private. My project doesn't have
a published interface outside the company, so anyone who misuses
protected methods is within easy reach of my big, fat cluebat.

My unit tests sit in the same package (but not the same project
directory) as the classes under test, so my unit tests can access
anything which is public or protected. Works great. The few
items I really do have set private are usually
things-that-can't-possibly-break, anyway.
